S1.T1.caption:
Table 1: Communication and computation cost of the proposed CCESA algorithm, scalable secure aggregation algorithm in parallel workÂ (Bell etÂ al., 2020), Secure Aggregation (SA) inÂ (Bonawitz etÂ al., 2017).
Detailed derivations of complexity are given in Appendix C.
references: We propose communication-computation efficient secure aggregation (CCESA) algorithm, which maintains the reliability and data privacy in federated learning with reduced resources on communication and computation compared to conventional secure aggregation ofÂ (Bonawitz etÂ al., 2017). The key idea is to replace the complete graph topology ofÂ (Bonawitz etÂ al., 2017) with a low-degree graph for resource efficiency, as illustrated in Fig.Â 1. Under the threat of eavesdroppers, we first provide the necessary and sufficient condition on the sparse graph topology for private and reliable secure aggregation and suggest an explicit graph design rule based on a conceptually simple Erdos-Renyi graph. As a consequence, the required resources of the proposed CCESA reduce by a factor of at least Oâ€‹(n/logâ¡n)ğ‘‚ğ‘›ğ‘›O(\sqrt{n/\log n}) compared toÂ (Bonawitz etÂ al., 2017). Here, we acknowledge that parallel workÂ (Bell etÂ al., 2020) utilizes a Harary graph topology where each client more effectively selects the clients sharing its secret, and consequently further reduces communication/computation costs of secure aggregation. Detailed comparisons are given in TableÂ 1. Our mathematical results are also confirmed in experiments on two real datasets of AT&T face database and CIFAR-10, under practical attack scenarios including the model inversion attack and the membership inference attack. Especially, under the model inversion attack on the face dataset, the results in Fig.Â 2 show that the suggested scheme achieves near-perfect data privacy by using less amount of resources than SA, while federated averaging without security measuresÂ (McMahan etÂ al., 2017) significantly compromises the privacy of the data.

In the remarks below, we compare SA and the proposed CCESA, in terms of the required amount of communication/computational resources to achieve both reliability and privacy. These results are summarized in TableÂ 1.

In TableÂ 5.1, we tested the running time of our CCESA and existing SA for various nğ‘›n and qtotalsubscriptğ‘totalq_{\text{total}}. Similar to the setup used inÂ (Bonawitz etÂ al., 2017), we assumed that each node has its local model ğœ½ğœ½\bm{\theta} with dimension m=10000ğ‘š10000m=10000, where each element of the model is chosen from the field ğ”½216subscriptğ”½superscript216\mathbb{F}_{2^{16}}. Here, tğ‘¡t is selected by following the guideline
in Appendix E, and pğ‘p is chosen as pâ‹†âˆ¼Oâ€‹(logâ¡n/n)similar-tosuperscriptğ‘â‹†ğ‘‚ğ‘›ğ‘›p^{\star}\sim O(\sqrt{\log n/n}) defined in (5) which is proven to meet both reliability and privacy conditions.
For every n,qtotalğ‘›subscriptğ‘totaln,q_{\text{total}} setup, the proposed CCESA(n,pğ‘›ğ‘n,p) requires pğ‘p times less running time compared with the conventional SA ofÂ (Bonawitz etÂ al., 2017).
This is because each client generates pğ‘p times less number of secret shares and pseudo-random values, and performs pğ‘p times less number of key agreements. This result is consistent with our analysis on the computational complexity in TableÂ 1.

as nğ‘›n increases, showing the scalability of CCESA.
These results are summarized in TableÂ 1.

We evaluate the computational cost of CCESA.
Here we do not count the cost for computing the signatures since it is negligible. First, we derive the computational cost of each client.
Given the number of model parameters mğ‘šm and the number of clients nğ‘›n, the computational cost of client iğ‘–i is composed of three parts:
(1) computing 2â€‹|Aâ€‹dâ€‹jâ€‹(i)|2ğ´ğ‘‘ğ‘—ğ‘–2|Adj(i)| key agreements, which takes Oâ€‹(|Aâ€‹dâ€‹jâ€‹(i)|)ğ‘‚ğ´ğ‘‘ğ‘—ğ‘–O(|Adj(i)|) time,
(2) generating shares of tisubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘–t_{i}-out-of-|Aâ€‹dâ€‹jâ€‹(i)|ğ´ğ‘‘ğ‘—ğ‘–|Adj(i)| secret shares of siSâ€‹Ksuperscriptsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘–ğ‘†ğ¾s_{i}^{SK} and bisubscriptğ‘ğ‘–b_{i}, which takes Oâ€‹(|Aâ€‹dâ€‹jâ€‹(i)|2)ğ‘‚superscriptğ´ğ‘‘ğ‘—ğ‘–2O(|Adj(i)|^{2}) time, and
(3) generating masked local model Î¸~isubscript~ğœƒğ‘–\tilde{\theta}_{i}, which requires Oâ€‹(mâ€‹|Aâ€‹dâ€‹jâ€‹(i)|)ğ‘‚ğ‘šğ´ğ‘‘ğ‘—ğ‘–O(m|Adj(i)|) time.
Thus, the total computational cost of each client is obtained as Oâ€‹(|Aâ€‹dâ€‹jâ€‹(i)|2+mâ€‹|Aâ€‹dâ€‹jâ€‹(i)|)ğ‘‚superscriptğ´ğ‘‘ğ‘—ğ‘–2ğ‘šğ´ğ‘‘ğ‘—ğ‘–O(|Adj(i)|^{2}+m|Adj(i)|).
Second, the serverâ€™s computational cost is composed of two parts:
(1) reconstructing tisubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘–t_{i}-out-of-|Aâ€‹dâ€‹jâ€‹(i)|ğ´ğ‘‘ğ‘—ğ‘–|Adj(i)| secrets from shares for all clients iâˆˆ[n]ğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘›i\in[n], which requires Oâ€‹(nâ€‹|Aâ€‹dâ€‹jâ€‹(i)|2)ğ‘‚ğ‘›superscriptğ´ğ‘‘ğ‘—ğ‘–2O(n|Adj(i)|^{2}) time, and (2) removing masks from masked sum of local models âˆ‘i=1nÎ¸~isuperscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘›subscript~ğœƒğ‘–\sum_{i=1}^{n}\tilde{\theta}_{i}, which requires Oâ€‹(mâ€‹|Aâ€‹dâ€‹jâ€‹(i)|2)ğ‘‚ğ‘šsuperscriptğ´ğ‘‘ğ‘—ğ‘–2O(m|Adj(i)|^{2}) time in the worst case.
As a result, the total computational cost of the server is Oâ€‹(mâ€‹|Aâ€‹dâ€‹jâ€‹(i)|2)ğ‘‚ğ‘šsuperscriptğ´ğ‘‘ğ‘—ğ‘–2O(m|Adj(i)|^{2}).
If we choose p=(1+Ïµ)â€‹pâ‹†ğ‘1italic-Ïµsuperscriptğ‘â‹†p=(1+\epsilon)p^{\star} for small Ïµ>0italic-Ïµ0\epsilon>0, the total computational cost per each client is Oâ€‹(nâ€‹logâ¡n+mâ€‹nâ€‹logâ¡n)ğ‘‚ğ‘›ğ‘›ğ‘šğ‘›ğ‘›O(n\log n+m\sqrt{n\log n}), while the total computation cost of the server is Oâ€‹(mâ€‹nâ€‹logâ¡n+n2â€‹logâ¡n)ğ‘‚ğ‘šğ‘›ğ‘›superscriptğ‘›2ğ‘›O(mn\log n+n^{2}\log n).
The computational cost of SA can be obtained in a similar manner, by setting Aâ€‹dâ€‹jâ€‹(i)=nâˆ’1ğ´ğ‘‘ğ‘—ğ‘–ğ‘›1Adj(i)=n-1; each client requires Oâ€‹(n2+mâ€‹n)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘›2ğ‘šğ‘›O(n^{2}+mn) time while the server requires Oâ€‹(mâ€‹n2)ğ‘‚ğ‘šsuperscriptğ‘›2O(mn^{2}) time. These results are summarized in TableÂ 1.

Combining the above two lemmas, we conclude that CCESA(n,pâ‹†ğ‘›superscriptğ‘â‹†n,p^{\star}) is private with probability â‰¥1âˆ’Oâ€‹(nâˆ’C)absent1ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘›ğ¶\geq 1-O(n^{-C}) for arbitrary C>0ğ¶0C>0.
These results on the reliability and the privacy are summarized in TableÂ 1.

S5.T2.caption:
Table 5.2: Accuracy of the membership inference attack on local models trained on CIFAR-10. The scheme with a higher attack accuracy is more vulnerable to the inference attack.
In order to maximize the uncertainty of the membership inference,
the test set for the attack model consists of 500050005000 members (training data points) and 500050005000 non-members (evaluation data points).
For the proposed CCESA, the attacker is no better than the random guess with accuracy = 50%percent5050\%, showing the privacy-preserving ability of CCESA.

references:
We first consider a privacy threat called model inversion attackÂ (Fredrikson etÂ al., 2015). The basic setup is as follows: the attacker eavesdrops the masked model Î¸~isubscript~ğœƒğ‘–\tilde{\theta}_{i} sent from client iğ‘–i to the server, and reconstructs the face image of a target client. Under this setting, we compared how the eavesdropped model reveals the information on the raw data for various schemes. As in Fig.Â 2 and Fig.Â A.4 in Appendix A.2, the vanilla federated averagingÂ (McMahan etÂ al., 2017) with no privacy-preserving techniques reveals the characteristics of individualâ€™s face, compromising the privacy of clients.
On the other hand, both SA and CCESA do not allow any clue on the clientâ€™s face; these schemes are resilient to the model inversion attack and preserve the privacy of clients.
This observation is consistent with our theoretical results
that the proposed CCESA guarantees data privacy.
We also considered another privacy threat called the membership inference attackÂ (Shokri etÂ al., 2017). Here, the attacker eavesdrops the masked model Î¸~isubscript~ğœƒğ‘–\tilde{\theta}_{i} and guesses whether a target data is a member of the training dataset.
TableÂ 5.2 summarizes the accuracy
of the inference attack for CIFAR-10 dataset, under the federated learning setup where ntrainsubscriptğ‘›trainn_{\text{train}} training data is equally distributed into n=10ğ‘›10n=10 clients.
The attack accuracy reaches near 70%percent7070\% for federated averaging, while SA and CCESA have the attack accuracy of near 50%percent5050\%, similar to the performance of the random guess.

In Section 5.3, we have also considered another type of privacy threat called membership inference attackÂ (Shokri etÂ al., 2017), where the attacker observes masked local model Î¸~isubscript~ğœƒğ‘–\tilde{\theta}_{i} sent from client iğ‘–i to the server, and guesses whether a particular data is the member of the training set.
We measured three types of performance metrics of the attacker: accuracy (the fraction of the records correctly estimated the membership), precision (the fraction of the responses inferred as members of the training dataset that are indeed members) and recall (the fraction of the training data that the attacker can correctly infer as members).
TableÂ 5.2 summarizes the attack accuracy result, while TableÂ A.3 shows the attack precision for CIFAR-10 dataset.
We also observed that recall is close to 111 for all schemes.
Similar to the results on the attack accuracy, TableÂ A.3 shows that the attack precision of federated averaging reaches near 70%percent7070\%, while that of SA and CCESA remain around the baseline performance of random guess.
This shows that both SA and CCESA do not reveal any clue on the training set.

A1.T3.caption:
Table A.3: Precision of the membership inference attack on local models trained on CIFAR-10. The scheme with a higher attack precision is more vulnerable to the inference attack.
For the proposed CCESA, the attacker is no better than the random guess with precision = 50%percent5050\%, showing the privacy-preserving ability of CCESA.

Another popular approach is deploying secure multiparty computation (MPC) Â (Ben-Or etÂ al., 1988; DamgÃ¥rd etÂ al., 2012; Aono etÂ al., 2017; Lindell etÂ al., 2015; Bonawitz etÂ al., 2017; Zhang etÂ al., 2018; Tjell & Wisniewski, 2019; Shen etÂ al., 2020; So etÂ al., 2020) based on the cryptographic primitives including secret sharing and the homomorphic encryptionÂ (Leontiadis etÂ al., 2014; 2015; Shi etÂ al., 2011; Halevi etÂ al., 2011).
Although these schemes guarantee privacy, they suffer from high communication burdens while reconstructing the secret information distributed over multiple clients.
A notable workÂ (Bonawitz etÂ al., 2017) suggested secure aggregation (SA), which tolerates multiple client failures by applying pairwise additive maskingÂ (Ãcs & Castelluccia, 2011; Elahi etÂ al., 2014; Jansen & Johnson, 2016; Goryczka & Xiong, 2015).
A recent workÂ (So etÂ al., 2020) suggested Turbo-aggregate, an approach based on the circular aggregation topology to achieve a significant computation/communication complexity reduction in secure aggregation.
However, each client in Turbo-aggregate requires a communication cost of at least 4â€‹mâ€‹nâ€‹R/L4ğ‘šğ‘›ğ‘…ğ¿4mnR/L bits, which is much larger than that of our scheme (CCESA) requiring a communication cost of nâ€‹logâ¡nâ€‹(2â€‹aK+5â€‹aS)+mâ€‹Rğ‘›ğ‘›2subscriptğ‘ğ¾5subscriptğ‘ğ‘†ğ‘šğ‘…\sqrt{n\log n}(2a_{K}+5a_{S})+mR111Here, mğ‘šm is the number of model parameters where each parameter is represented in Rğ‘…R bits. Lğ¿L is the number of client groups in Turbo-aggregate. aKsubscriptğ‘ğ¾a_{K} and aSsubscriptğ‘ğ‘†a_{S} are the number of bits required for exchanging public keys and the number of bits in a secret share, respectively.. For example, in a practical scenario with m=106,R=32,n=100,L=10formulae-sequenceğ‘šsuperscript106formulae-sequenceğ‘…32formulae-sequenceğ‘›100ğ¿10m=10^{6},R=32,n=100,L=10 and aK=aS=256subscriptğ‘ğ¾subscriptğ‘ğ‘†256a_{K}=a_{S}=256, our scheme requires only 3%percent33\% of the communication bandwidth used in Turbo-aggregate.

Here we do not count the cost for computing the signatures since it is negligible. First, we derive the computational cost of each client.

AT&T Face dataset contains images of 404040 members. We allocated the data to n=40ğ‘›40n=40 clients participating in the federated learning, where each client contains the images of a specific member. This experimental setup is suitable for the practical federated learning scenario where each client has its own image and the central server aggregates the local models for face recognition.
Following the previous workÂ (Fredrikson etÂ al., 2015) on the model inversion, we used softmax regression for the classification. Both the number of local training epochs and the number of global aggregation rounds are set to Elâ€‹oâ€‹câ€‹aâ€‹l=Egâ€‹lâ€‹oâ€‹bâ€‹aâ€‹l=50subscriptğ¸ğ‘™ğ‘œğ‘ğ‘ğ‘™subscriptğ¸ğ‘”ğ‘™ğ‘œğ‘ğ‘ğ‘™50E_{local}=E_{global}=50, and we used the SGD optimizer with learning rate Î³=0.05ğ›¾0.05\gamma=0.05.

In Fig.Â 4.1, we select different connection probabilities p=pâ‹†â€‹(n,qtotal)ğ‘superscriptğ‘â‹†ğ‘›subscriptğ‘totalp=p^{\star}(n,q_{\text{total}}) for various nğ‘›n and qtotalsubscriptğ‘totalq_{\text{total}}, where pâ‹†superscriptğ‘â‹†p^{\star} is defined in (5).

references: We propose communication-computation efficient secure aggregation (CCESA) algorithm, which maintains the reliability and data privacy in federated learning with reduced resources on communication and computation compared to conventional secure aggregation ofÂ (Bonawitz etÂ al., 2017). The key idea is to replace the complete graph topology ofÂ (Bonawitz etÂ al., 2017) with a low-degree graph for resource efficiency, as illustrated in Fig.Â 1. Under the threat of eavesdroppers, we first provide the necessary and sufficient condition on the sparse graph topology for private and reliable secure aggregation and suggest an explicit graph design rule based on a conceptually simple Erdos-Renyi graph. As a consequence, the required resources of the proposed CCESA reduce by a factor of at least Oâ€‹(n/logâ¡n)ğ‘‚ğ‘›ğ‘›O(\sqrt{n/\log n}) compared toÂ (Bonawitz etÂ al., 2017). Here, we acknowledge that parallel workÂ (Bell etÂ al., 2020) utilizes a Harary graph topology where each client more effectively selects the clients sharing its secret, and consequently further reduces communication/computation costs of secure aggregation. Detailed comparisons are given in TableÂ 1. Our mathematical results are also confirmed in experiments on two real datasets of AT&T face database and CIFAR-10, under practical attack scenarios including the model inversion attack and the membership inference attack. Especially, under the model inversion attack on the face dataset, the results in Fig.Â 2 show that the suggested scheme achieves near-perfect data privacy by using less amount of resources than SA, while federated averaging without security measuresÂ (McMahan etÂ al., 2017) significantly compromises the privacy of the data.

Another popular approach is deploying secure multiparty computation (MPC) Â (Ben-Or etÂ al., 1988; DamgÃ¥rd etÂ al., 2012; Aono etÂ al., 2017; Lindell etÂ al., 2015; Bonawitz etÂ al., 2017; Zhang etÂ al., 2018; Tjell & Wisniewski, 2019; Shen etÂ al., 2020; So etÂ al., 2020) based on the cryptographic primitives including secret sharing and the homomorphic encryptionÂ (Leontiadis etÂ al., 2014; 2015; Shi etÂ al., 2011; Halevi etÂ al., 2011).
Although these schemes guarantee privacy, they suffer from high communication burdens while reconstructing the secret information distributed over multiple clients.
A notable workÂ (Bonawitz etÂ al., 2017) suggested secure aggregation (SA), which tolerates multiple client failures by applying pairwise additive maskingÂ (Ãcs & Castelluccia, 2011; Elahi etÂ al., 2014; Jansen & Johnson, 2016; Goryczka & Xiong, 2015).
A recent workÂ (So etÂ al., 2020) suggested Turbo-aggregate, an approach based on the circular aggregation topology to achieve a significant computation/communication complexity reduction in secure aggregation.
However, each client in Turbo-aggregate requires a communication cost of at least 4â€‹mâ€‹nâ€‹R/L4ğ‘šğ‘›ğ‘…ğ¿4mnR/L bits, which is much larger than that of our scheme (CCESA) requiring a communication cost of nâ€‹logâ¡nâ€‹(2â€‹aK+5â€‹aS)+mâ€‹Rğ‘›ğ‘›2subscriptğ‘ğ¾5subscriptğ‘ğ‘†ğ‘šğ‘…\sqrt{n\log n}(2a_{K}+5a_{S})+mR111Here, mğ‘šm is the number of model parameters where each parameter is represented in Rğ‘…R bits. Lğ¿L is the number of client groups in Turbo-aggregate. aKsubscriptğ‘ğ¾a_{K} and aSsubscriptğ‘ğ‘†a_{S} are the number of bits required for exchanging public keys and the number of bits in a secret share, respectively.. For example, in a practical scenario with m=106,R=32,n=100,L=10formulae-sequenceğ‘šsuperscript106formulae-sequenceğ‘…32formulae-sequenceğ‘›100ğ¿10m=10^{6},R=32,n=100,L=10 and aK=aS=256subscriptğ‘ğ¾subscriptğ‘ğ‘†256a_{K}=a_{S}=256, our scheme requires only 3%percent33\% of the communication bandwidth used in Turbo-aggregate.

In the remarks below, we compare SA and the proposed CCESA, in terms of the required amount of communication/computational resources to achieve both reliability and privacy. These results are summarized in TableÂ 1.

In TableÂ 5.1, we tested the running time of our CCESA and existing SA for various nğ‘›n and qtotalsubscriptğ‘totalq_{\text{total}}. Similar to the setup used inÂ (Bonawitz etÂ al., 2017), we assumed that each node has its local model ğœ½ğœ½\bm{\theta} with dimension m=10000ğ‘š10000m=10000, where each element of the model is chosen from the field ğ”½216subscriptğ”½superscript216\mathbb{F}_{2^{16}}. Here, tğ‘¡t is selected by following the guideline
in Appendix E, and pğ‘p is chosen as pâ‹†âˆ¼Oâ€‹(logâ¡n/n)similar-tosuperscriptğ‘â‹†ğ‘‚ğ‘›ğ‘›p^{\star}\sim O(\sqrt{\log n/n}) defined in (5) which is proven to meet both reliability and privacy conditions.
For every n,qtotalğ‘›subscriptğ‘totaln,q_{\text{total}} setup, the proposed CCESA(n,pğ‘›ğ‘n,p) requires pğ‘p times less running time compared with the conventional SA ofÂ (Bonawitz etÂ al., 2017).
This is because each client generates pğ‘p times less number of secret shares and pseudo-random values, and performs pğ‘p times less number of key agreements. This result is consistent with our analysis on the computational complexity in TableÂ 1.

We first consider a privacy threat called model inversion attackÂ (Fredrikson etÂ al., 2015). The basic setup is as follows: the attacker eavesdrops the masked model Î¸~isubscript~ğœƒğ‘–\tilde{\theta}_{i} sent from client iğ‘–i to the server, and reconstructs the face image of a target client. Under this setting, we compared how the eavesdropped model reveals the information on the raw data for various schemes. As in Fig.Â 2 and Fig.Â A.4 in Appendix A.2, the vanilla federated averagingÂ (McMahan etÂ al., 2017) with no privacy-preserving techniques reveals the characteristics of individualâ€™s face, compromising the privacy of clients.
On the other hand, both SA and CCESA do not allow any clue on the clientâ€™s face; these schemes are resilient to the model inversion attack and preserve the privacy of clients.
This observation is consistent with our theoretical results
that the proposed CCESA guarantees data privacy.
We also considered another privacy threat called the membership inference attackÂ (Shokri etÂ al., 2017). Here, the attacker eavesdrops the masked model Î¸~isubscript~ğœƒğ‘–\tilde{\theta}_{i} and guesses whether a target data is a member of the training dataset.
TableÂ 5.2 summarizes the accuracy
of the inference attack for CIFAR-10 dataset, under the federated learning setup where ntrainsubscriptğ‘›trainn_{\text{train}} training data is equally distributed into n=10ğ‘›10n=10 clients.
The attack accuracy reaches near 70%percent7070\% for federated averaging, while SA and CCESA have the attack accuracy of near 50%percent5050\%, similar to the performance of the random guess.

In Section 5.3, we have also considered another type of privacy threat called membership inference attackÂ (Shokri etÂ al., 2017), where the attacker observes masked local model Î¸~isubscript~ğœƒğ‘–\tilde{\theta}_{i} sent from client iğ‘–i to the server, and guesses whether a particular data is the member of the training set.
We measured three types of performance metrics of the attacker: accuracy (the fraction of the records correctly estimated the membership), precision (the fraction of the responses inferred as members of the training dataset that are indeed members) and recall (the fraction of the training data that the attacker can correctly infer as members).
TableÂ 5.2 summarizes the attack accuracy result, while TableÂ A.3 shows the attack precision for CIFAR-10 dataset.
We also observed that recall is close to 111 for all schemes.
Similar to the results on the attack accuracy, TableÂ A.3 shows that the attack precision of federated averaging reaches near 70%percent7070\%, while that of SA and CCESA remain around the baseline performance of random guess.
This shows that both SA and CCESA do not reveal any clue on the training set.

as nğ‘›n increases, showing the scalability of CCESA.
These results are summarized in TableÂ 1.

We evaluate the computational cost of CCESA.
Here we do not count the cost for computing the signatures since it is negligible. First, we derive the computational cost of each client.
Given the number of model parameters mğ‘šm and the number of clients nğ‘›n, the computational cost of client iğ‘–i is composed of three parts:
(1) computing 2â€‹|Aâ€‹dâ€‹jâ€‹(i)|2ğ´ğ‘‘ğ‘—ğ‘–2|Adj(i)| key agreements, which takes Oâ€‹(|Aâ€‹dâ€‹jâ€‹(i)|)ğ‘‚ğ´ğ‘‘ğ‘—ğ‘–O(|Adj(i)|) time,
(2) generating shares of tisubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘–t_{i}-out-of-|Aâ€‹dâ€‹jâ€‹(i)|ğ´ğ‘‘ğ‘—ğ‘–|Adj(i)| secret shares of siSâ€‹Ksuperscriptsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘–ğ‘†ğ¾s_{i}^{SK} and bisubscriptğ‘ğ‘–b_{i}, which takes Oâ€‹(|Aâ€‹dâ€‹jâ€‹(i)|2)ğ‘‚superscriptğ´ğ‘‘ğ‘—ğ‘–2O(|Adj(i)|^{2}) time, and
(3) generating masked local model Î¸~isubscript~ğœƒğ‘–\tilde{\theta}_{i}, which requires Oâ€‹(mâ€‹|Aâ€‹dâ€‹jâ€‹(i)|)ğ‘‚ğ‘šğ´ğ‘‘ğ‘—ğ‘–O(m|Adj(i)|) time.
Thus, the total computational cost of each client is obtained as Oâ€‹(|Aâ€‹dâ€‹jâ€‹(i)|2+mâ€‹|Aâ€‹dâ€‹jâ€‹(i)|)ğ‘‚superscriptğ´ğ‘‘ğ‘—ğ‘–2ğ‘šğ´ğ‘‘ğ‘—ğ‘–O(|Adj(i)|^{2}+m|Adj(i)|).
Second, the serverâ€™s computational cost is composed of two parts:
(1) reconstructing tisubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘–t_{i}-out-of-|Aâ€‹dâ€‹jâ€‹(i)|ğ´ğ‘‘ğ‘—ğ‘–|Adj(i)| secrets from shares for all clients iâˆˆ[n]ğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘›i\in[n], which requires Oâ€‹(nâ€‹|Aâ€‹dâ€‹jâ€‹(i)|2)ğ‘‚ğ‘›superscriptğ´ğ‘‘ğ‘—ğ‘–2O(n|Adj(i)|^{2}) time, and (2) removing masks from masked sum of local models âˆ‘i=1nÎ¸~isuperscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘›subscript~ğœƒğ‘–\sum_{i=1}^{n}\tilde{\theta}_{i}, which requires Oâ€‹(mâ€‹|Aâ€‹dâ€‹jâ€‹(i)|2)ğ‘‚ğ‘šsuperscriptğ´ğ‘‘ğ‘—ğ‘–2O(m|Adj(i)|^{2}) time in the worst case.
As a result, the total computational cost of the server is Oâ€‹(mâ€‹|Aâ€‹dâ€‹jâ€‹(i)|2)ğ‘‚ğ‘šsuperscriptğ´ğ‘‘ğ‘—ğ‘–2O(m|Adj(i)|^{2}).

Combining the above two lemmas, we conclude that CCESA(n,pâ‹†ğ‘›superscriptğ‘â‹†n,p^{\star}) is private with probability â‰¥1âˆ’Oâ€‹(nâˆ’C)absent1ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘›ğ¶\geq 1-O(n^{-C}) for arbitrary C>0ğ¶0C>0.

AT&T Face dataset contains images of 404040 members. We allocated the data to n=40ğ‘›40n=40 clients participating in the federated learning, where each client contains the images of a specific member. This experimental setup is suitable for the practical federated learning scenario where each client has its own image and the central server aggregates the local models for face recognition.
Following the previous workÂ (Fredrikson etÂ al., 2015) on the model inversion, we used softmax regression for the classification. Both the number of local training epochs and the number of global aggregation rounds are set to Elâ€‹oâ€‹câ€‹aâ€‹l=Egâ€‹lâ€‹oâ€‹bâ€‹aâ€‹l=50subscriptğ¸ğ‘™ğ‘œğ‘ğ‘ğ‘™subscriptğ¸ğ‘”ğ‘™ğ‘œğ‘ğ‘ğ‘™50E_{local}=E_{global}=50, and we used the SGD optimizer with learning rate Î³=0.05ğ›¾0.05\gamma=0.05.
